newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: KL short-term rates rise on foreign bank covering.
newsitem.headline: KL short-term rates rise on foreign bank covering.

text.p: Short-term interbank rates rose sharply as foreign banks covered their short positions, dealers said on Wednesday.
They said one-week money was up at 7.45/50 percent against 6.90/7.00, two-week was at 7.45/50 against 7.00/10 and one-month at 7.25/30 against 7.20/22.
However, medium and long-term rates were nearly steady at the previous levels. Three-month money at 7.25/30 percent and six-month at 7.30/35 were both unchanged.
"Foreign and some big banks are lending longer-term because they view interest rates will be stable around this level," said a dealer with a local bank.
He said the market was short on funds up to one-month money though overall liquidity was adequate.
Some dealers said the rate rise was also in reaction to the overnight rate remaining above 8.0 percent in the last two days. It ended at 8.30 percent on Tuesday.
"Everybody who has funds is lending long-term. This has also pushed up swaps on the short-end," said a dealer with a foreign bank.
She said it was also possible that large banks had overlent to the central bank at its intervention on Friday.
Bank Negara regularly intervenes in the domestic money market to keep liquidity under check and set interest rates.

Another money market dealer said banks were probably also locking up their funds in long-term deposits before interbank rates dropped after an 800-million ringgit maturity of Government bonds on October 15.
